div.h1: Coronavirus and CUSD School Closure Details

p.span: Chandler Unified continues to be updated frequently by the Arizona Department of Health Services and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention regarding the Coronavirus. Should there be a need to update our parents and community on anything regarding the Coronavirus COVID-19, official information will be shared through email and on our district website.

h1.aria-label: Message from CUSD Superintendent Camille Casteel, 4-9-2020
h1.span: Message from CUSD Superintendent Camille Casteel, 4-9-2020

p.span: April 9, 2020
Dear CUSD Families,

We are in our 13th day of school closure since returning from the two-week intersession. I know there are still unanswered questions and we will be addressing all of them in the days ahead. Recapping what has been done to-date:

li.span: We are serving an excess of 20,000 meals to our most vulnerable students three times a week.
Childcare is being provided to children of medical professionals so they can tend to the needs of our community.
Arrangements have been made for parents to pick up medications.

Families have been surveyed to determine technology needs. At the secondary level, we are providing Chromebooks and hotspots to the students with the highest needs. Teachers are at various levels of comfort utilizing technology to interact with students. We are training teachers on Google Hangouts/Meets/ and Microsoft Teams for live synchronized discussions.
Additionally, Google Classroom is more broadly used among our secondary teachers and we have initiated training with the technology leaders at each elementary school.
We have sought parent permission for students to be online, in compliance with federal regulations that require us to set up safeguards, particularly for children 13 and under.
Instructional packets are being produced and distributed for the most part at elementary schools. Teachers are being encouraged to contact their students by way of phone, email, and Google Meets.
State and National testing has been suspended, postponed or adjusted: District and State Testing - School Closure Update
Construction of our new schools, Rice Elementary to open in July and high school to open in 2021 remain on schedule.

p.span: Future steps:

li.span: We will communicate how your child can acquire their personal items in classrooms, lockers, desks, etc. and return items that belong to the school. You can rest assured, our facilities will be sanitized, and we are taking all precautions, should you need to enter the campus.
We are actively working on potential summer school opportunities so that we can be ready to help students review and get prepared for the 2020-21 school year.

Grading guidelines are being distributed this week by your school principal. You will see that there are differences between elementary, junior high and high school: CUSD Grading Plan for 4th quarter home instruction due to school closure

We know there are many questions about graduation. We are delaying a final decision on graduation and other end-of-the-year celebrations in hopes that we will have greater insight into the status of the pandemic.

p.span: I would encourage you to maintain contact with your site administrator and individual teacher(s) with questions related to instruction.

We understand there is tremendous demand on families who have limited technology in their homes and multiple family members who need access. We are moving cautiously and deliberately in order to consider our decisions from all perspectives. The stress level is high for everyone involved and, at this point, we are committed to doing everything we can to minimize the additional pressure we are applying so that you can more easily prioritize the health and safety of your family.
With prayers and positive thoughts for a speedy resolve.
Sincerely,

h1.aria-label: CUSD Elementary Grading Plan for 4th quarter home instruction due to school closure - 4/8/2020
h1.span: CUSD Elementary Grading Plan for 4th quarter home instruction due to school closure - 4/8/2020

p.span: Students will earn a Pass/Fail grade in the subjects of Mathematics and English Language Arts (ELA) for the 4th quarter of the 2019 – 2020 school year. The home instructional focus of the assignments is to provide preparation for the next grade level, and will be delivered online or through hard copy resources. The following guidelines will be utilized for elementary school grading.
A passing grade will be issued to students who:

li.span: attempt and engage in the lessons assigned
participate in teacher check-ins, a
nd
show reasonable progression

p.span: During home instruction, an elementary student’s 4th quarter grade can only improve upon their 3rd quarter grade.
Printed materials in core content areas will be available (days and times specific to your site) for pick up by students that do not have access to lessons online.

h1.aria-label: CUSD High School and Junior High Grading Plans - 4/7/2020
h1.span: CUSD High School and Junior High Grading Plans - 4/7/2020

p.span: Students will earn a letter grade for the second semester, which will be a combination of their 3rd quarter grades and work completed during 4th quarter. The instructional focus of the assignments is to provide preparation for the next grade level, and will be delivered virtually or through hard copy resources. The following guidelines will be utilized for high school grading:

li.span: Work completed during the 4th quarter can only improve 3rd quarter grades.
Grades in infinite Campus will not accurately reflect the final semester grade.
A max of 2 assignments per week will be input into a teacher’s gradebook per the due dates assigned by the teacher.
A student’s grade can only improve by one letter grade.

Students who do not engage in online learning opportunities, or who cease to actively complete 4th quarter instructional activities, will receive their grades as they were posted at the end of 3rd quarter.
No finals will be included in the semester grade.
Any student failing can be given work to bring the grade up to passing.

p.span: Dual Credit

Students will need to keep up with the online work provided by their Dual Enrollment teacher(s). Students must demonstrate minimum competencies/skills, as determined by the community college, to finish the semester and earn credit. Although a student's grade can not drop for CUSD, the grade can drop for Chandler Gilbert Community College if a student does not complete assignments. With this in mind, it is important for dual enrollment students to complete the required assignments to maintain or improve their grade for CGCC. Chandler Gilbert Community College will work with CUSD teachers to ensure that students who successfully complete the dual enrollment coursework will earn their college credit.

Students will earn a Pass/Fail grade for the second semester, which will be a combination of their 3rd quarter grades and work completed during 4th quarter. The instructional focus of the assignments is to provide preparation for the next grade level, and will be delivered virtually or through hard copy resources. The following guidelines will be utilized for junior high school grading:

li.span: A student’s semester grade can only improve
Completed assignments will be tracked through Infinite Campus or Google Classroom
Students with a failing grade at 3rd quarter can improve to Pass for the semester, based on individual teacher expectations
Printed materials in core content areas will be available (days and times specific to your site) for pick up by students that do not have access to technology

p.span: Dear Chandler Parents and Families,

Governor Ducey and Superintendent Kathy Hoffman announced this morning, March 30, 2020, that schools will be closed for the remainder of the school year. Click here for the statement from the Governor’s office: Governor Ducey, Superintendent Hoffman Announce Extension Of School Closures Through End Of School Year.

We will be following up with more information to answer the multitude of questions you have regarding the end of the year related to grades, graduation, transcripts, scholarships, summer school, and continued instruction, etc. We need your continued patience as we plan and coordinate with other district and state officials.

Most of us have never experienced this level of disruption and uncertainty in our lifetime. I know our families are concerned about the health of their family members and neighbors and many are facing economic challenges. Your child’s safety and health is our top priority, and we will continue to work hard to minimize the impact related to their education. Please continue to check your email for frequent updates. For the latest information related to services and learning, please visit www.cusd80.com/COVID19. All resources will be located in one place for easy access for families.
Praying for the health and safety of all.
Camille Casteel, Ed.D

h1.aria-label: Message from CUSD Superintendent Camille Casteel, 3-27-2020
h1.span: Message from CUSD Superintendent Camille Casteel, 3-27-2020

p.span: March 27, 2020
Dear Chandler Parents and Families,

As you know, Governor Ducey extended school closures through April 10, and could possibly go longer. We share your concerns and continue to work with state officials every day to get the most current guidance and direction.

This week, the teachers returned to work after our two-week spring intersession and we have been working with them on ways to instruct and interact with their students remotely. First of all, we encouraged teachers and staff to reach out to families and continue to provide contact and support.
Our Chandler Emergency Management Team has been collaborating on services and we are able to update you on the following:

li.span: Curbside meal pick-up for students has been implemented and continues to expand locations.
Childcare is available for emergency essential workers including healthcare and first responders.
Teachers and support staff have been participating in professional development and receiving resources to prepare them for the adjusted online/remote learning environment.

A technology survey was distributed to families in order to determine student access to online learning resources. Schools are working to determine who needs additional support and/or non-digital alternatives. School leaders will communicate procedures for distribution of paper materials to families who need assistance.

March 30 will be the start of students’ remote learning activities. Teachers will communicate directly to students. Please remember, these lessons are designed to reinforce and enrich student skills while schools are closed. They are not meant to add additional stress to an already difficult time. We have worked with teachers to remain cognizant that multiple people, including parents, may be using any technology available in the home and to plan accordingly. Communicate with your teachers if you have any questions or concerns.
Students in PreK-6 will have assignments and activity opportunities. There will be no official grading/collection of these assignments at this time due to the school closure.
Students in grades 7-12 will participate in Google Classroom or Buzz /Agilex platforms. Completion of assignments will only be used to improve a student’s grade.
Parental tips for creating a successful learning environment in the home:
Create a consistent daily routine
Build a schedule that involves studying and physical breaks
Access our enrichment page if you are looking for more activities than the lessons provided
Review digital citizenship guidelines listed on our distance learning webpage in order to protect student privacy while online
Stay connected with your teachers
Ask for assistance from teachers, if needed

p.span: Realizing you have many questions regarding the next several weeks, we will continue to keep communication avenues open. Please check your email for frequent updates from your teachers. For the latest updates related to services and learning, please continue to visit www.cusd80.com/COVID19. All resources will be located in one place for easy access for families.

Our efforts are focused on doing what we can to ensure the safety of our entire community as we move forward. We will continue to monitor the situation, follow the Center for Disease Control (CDC) prevention guidelines and provide information to parents as it becomes available.
Respectfully,
Camille Casteel, Ed.D

h1.aria-label: Distance Learning Plan During School Closure for CUSD Students - 3/27/2020
h1.span: Distance Learning Plan During School Closure for CUSD Students - 3/27/2020

p.span: March 27, 2020
Dear Chandler Unified School District Parents and Guardians,

The K-12 Educational Services Department has collaborated to provide our students with a learning plan which addresses our diverse academic pathways across the K-12 spectrum during the school closure. When developing the academic tasks, the following considerations were discussed:

li.span: Instructional focus of assignments to provide a baseline for teachers to enrich or intervene with additional resources
Consistency in assignments to allow for collaboration amongst teaching staff
Equity in the ability to print the assignments for distribution to provide access
Schedules of assignments and assessments to provide a structure for learning in the home
Management of time for those households that need to share devices with parents, guardians and siblings

span.strong: The following are the designated learning pathways for elementary and secondary:

p.span: Using our adopted resources, K-6 teachers will be providing three assignments through e-mail each week of the closure in the content areas of English Language Arts and Math (6 total assignments each week). Each assignment is designed to be no longer than 35 minutes. K-6 teachers may provide enrichment activities to supplement the assignments. In addition to the three assignments for the two core areas, weekly assessments will be assigned to support the standards reviewed in the 4th Quarter. Preschool teachers will be providing a list of enrichment resources in addition to the monthly activity calendar. Preschool teachers will continue to focus upon the social-emotional connection with your child during the closure as we seek to meet the developmental needs of our youngest Chandler Unified students. Teachers will be collaborating with Special Education teachers and English Language Development teachers to ensure modifications or accommodations are made to the assignments to address individual student goals. You will be informed of the details of the assignments and resources through an email sent by your child’s teacher. Additionally, hard-copy packets of the assignments will be available weekly for families that do not have access to technology. Please communicate with your child’s teacher regarding the need for a hard-copy instructional packet.

We have asked teachers to plan short lessons that should take no more than 20 minutes to completing the 2-3 lessons per week. Teachers will be utilizing Google Classroom or Buzz to deliver instructional content, depending on the site. Specific resources and collaboration spaces were shared with secondary teachers. Teachers will be collaborating with Special Education teachers and English Language Development teachers to ensure modifications or accommodations are made for student goals for applicable assignments. You will be informed of the details of the assignments through an email sent by your student’s teacher(s). Additionally, hard-copy packets of the assignments will be available for students that do not have access to technology. Please communicate with your student’s teachers regarding the need for a hard-copy instructional packet.
For more information regarding distance learning communication and information regarding electronic access, please visit the CUSD Distance Learning website below:

Teachers will be available for online contact with students Monday through Friday during regular school hours to clarify content and provide answers to general questions. Our goal is to provide our students with a manageable, consistent set of assignments as a means of keeping our students connected to their school during this unprecedented event. Thank you for your partnership in education.
K-12 Educational Services Team
Chandler Unified School District

h1.aria-label: Short survey related to technology access and devices at home - 3/23/2020
h1.span: Short survey related to technology access and devices at home - 3/23/2020

p.span: Dear Parents / Guardians,

We are inviting you to take a short survey related to technology access and devices at home. This will assist us in planning for our instructional support. Please complete the survey by Wednesday, March 25.
Survey link: https://bit.ly/CUSDFamilyTechnology
Thank you in advance for your completion.
Chandler Unified School District

We want to provide you the latest information regarding school closings related to COVID19. This afternoon, Governor Doug Ducey and Superintendent Kathy Hoffman today announced a two-week extension of school closures through Friday, April 10, 2020. Click here for the statement from the Governor’s office: Governor Ducey, Superintendent Hoffman Announce Two-Week Extension Of School Closures. Accordingly, our schools and school offices, district office, grounds and fields will remain closed to the public until further notice.

We understand there is anxiety regarding a number of issues related to the closure and the balance of the school year. We will continue to provide you with information updates via email and text, and posted online at www.cusd80.com/COVID19. We thank you for your patience and understanding.

h1.aria-label: CUSD Update 3/18/2020: Schools Closed to Public
h1.span: CUSD Update 3/18/2020: Schools Closed to Public

p.span: As you know, Governor Doug Ducey and State Superintendent of Public Instruction Kathy Hoffman announced statewide school closures through March 27. As a result, our school offices, district office, grounds and fields are closed to the public until further notice. All activities, athletic games, practices, competitions, tryouts, clinics and events are canceled as well.
Childcare will continue for the remainder of this week.

Our food and nutrition department will continue to provide free meals through March 27. Should schools remain open past this date, we will continue to service children 18 and under. Details about the program’s hours and locations can be found at www.cusd80.com/CurbsideMeals.
Should you require immediate assistance, please call your school’s office or the district office (480) 812-7000. School phone numbers are available online at: www.cusd80.com/OurSchools

We understand there is anxiety regarding a number of issues related to the closure and the balance of the school year. We will continue to provide you with information each week. In addition, it will also be posted online at www.cusd80.com/COVID19. We thank you for your patience and understanding.
Update Regarding Novel Coronavirus and School Closures

Having an extended spring break afforded us a greater window to review the most current information about the coronavirus containment and consult with state leaders. Governor Doug Ducey announced this afternoon that all public schools in Arizona will close through March 27th. Our Kids Express intersession program will remain open this week for families who need the care.

We understand the hardship this may create for many of you and we are working on options to help meet the needs of our parents and community. We will communicate follow-up information by mid-week. Thank you for your patience and understanding.
CUSD Emergency Management Team
March 13, 2020
Dear CUSD Parents and Staff,

As we reach the mid-point of spring break, we would like to provide an update regarding our actions and plans related to protecting students, staff and the community from the Coronavirus. We are taking this issue very seriously and are closely monitoring updates from national, state and county health experts.

Governor Ducey, State Superintendent Kathy Hoffman, and Director of Arizona Department of Health Services Dr. Cara Christ provided direction on Thursday afternoon, March 12th, advising school districts to remain open based on current information. Dr. Christ shared with school leaders that school closures could potentially lead to an increase in community spread if students were to be placed in a different congregate area outside of their regular communities for childcare purposes. Importantly, when community spread is minimal, keeping our schools open also provides children with a regular routine that helps reduce panic and fear.

It is important to note that there are no confirmed cases of Coronavirus in the Chandler Unified School District. CUSD is in a favorable position as students are not scheduled to return for another 11 days. At this time, CUSD is planning to resume classes on Tuesday, March 24th, with the following safeguards in place.
Students who have traveled to high-risk areas as identified by the CDC should self-isolate for 14 calendar days after their return. Absences will be excused.
Staff who have traveled to high-risk areas will be required to self-isolate for 14 calendar days after their return.
Out-of-state travel for students and staff has been suspended until further notice.
Although CUSD has an established system to keep schools clean, cleaning measures have been modified to minimize the spread of this specific virus.
Note: Parents who choose to keep their children home will have their absence excused.

The District Emergency Management Team will continue to meet daily to monitor and adjust actions as necessary to keep our students, families and employees healthy. We will provide updated information and address specific questions before the end of next week through School Messenger. In the meantime, follow the most current national and state updates on our website at www.cusd80.com/covid19.
Thank you for your patience and cooperation as we navigate these challenging times.
CUSD Emergency Management Team
Dear Parent/Guardian:

As you are probably aware, Maricopa County Department of Public Health recently confirmed one case of 2019 Novel Coronavirus in Maricopa County. This individual is a member of the ASU community and the risk to all Maricopa County residents, including the ASU community, is believed to be low at this time.
We understand that there is much concern over this new strain, and Maricopa County Public Health is committed to providing the most up-to-date information at www.maricopa.gov/coronavirus.

Maricopa County Public Health would like us to stress to our school community that in addition to flu, common strains of coronaviruses are often circulating in our community. While it would not be uncommon for a child to be diagnosed from a health care provider with a coronavirus, the 2019 Novel Coronavirus is only being tested through the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. This new strain of coronavirus has only been identified in individuals who have traveled to Wuhan, China.
Because protection from all respiratory viruses is similar, this is a good time to review precautions we can all use to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, such as the flu:

li.span: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick, and keep sick children home as well.
Cover your cough or sneeze, then immediately discard any tissues.
Clean and disinfect frequently-touched objects and surfaces.

p.span: Chandler Unified staff take these precautions in order to ensure a healthy learning environment for your children. We will keep you updated with any developments that could impact our families or schools.
If you have any questions, please contact CUSD Health Services Manager Lyndsay Hartley at 480-224-3763 or hartley.lyndsay@cusd80.com.
Sincerely,

span.strong: Update Regarding Novel Coronavirus from Maricopa County Department of Public Health 2-28-2020

p.span: Dear parents and guardians,

Please click here for an update letter about the Novel Coronavirus sent today from the Maricopa County Department of Public Health. Maricopa County also has more information and answers to Frequently Asked Questions at www.maricopa.gov/coronavirus.
Because protection from all respiratory viruses is similar, this is a good time to review precautions we can all use to prevent the spread of respiratory viruses, such as the flu:

li.span: Wash your hands often with soap and water for at least 20 seconds.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with unwashed hands.
Avoid close contact with people who are sick.
Stay home when you are sick, and keep sick children home as well.
Cover your cough or sneeze, then immediately discard any tissues.
Clean and disinfect frequently-touched objects and surfaces.

p.span: Chandler Unified staff take these precautions in order to ensure a healthy learning environment for your children.

We will keep you updated with any developments that could impact our families or schools. Updates will be sent to you using School Messenger – the same system used to send you this email. As always, if you change your email address or contact information, please be sure to notify your child’s school office of the change to ensure that you can stay informed. For your reference at any time, update letters are also posted to my website at www.cusd80.com/Superintendent and the CUSD Health Services website at www.cusd80.com/HealthServices. If you have any questions, please contact CUSD Health Services Manager Lyndsay Hartley at hartley.lyndsay@cusd80.com.
Sincerely,

h1.aria-label: Public Notice: Governing Board Meeting Procedures - April 17, 2020
h1.span: Public Notice: Governing Board Meeting Procedures - April 17, 2020

table.style: border: 2px solid #000000; background-color: #ffffe6; margin: 0px 10px 10px 0px; padding: 7px; max-width: 100%; text-align: left; border-collapse: collapse;

td.style: border: 2px solid #000000; padding: 10px; vertical-align: text-top; max-width: 100%;

p.span: Effective immediately and until further notice, the Chandler Unified School District Governing Board will be enforcing the Center for Disease Control’s health precautionary recommendation limiting all public gatherings to ten people. As such, the meeting will be held virtually with no public in-person attendance. There will be no Public Comments. Reference: Arizona Attorney General’s Opinion dated March 13, 2020 Re: Concerns Relating to Arizona’s Open Meeting Law and COVID-19.
All Governing Board meetings will be available to view via Facebook Live. To join the April 22, 2020 Meeting at 7:00 pm, please click on the link below:
